Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Effect of a cell-derived biological coating on a synthetic calcium phosphate scaffold on osteoblast behavior

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advances in tissue engineering have led to the development of numerous new biomaterials. Among these are calcium phosphate ceramics, used in bone tissue regeneration for healing of large bone voids due to trauma or disease. These biodegradable materials are compositionally similar to natural bone and thus integrate easily with developing or healing tissue. While these bone biomaterials are useful for bridging critical-sized defects, which are gaps in the bone tissue too large to heal without surgical intervention, it could be possible to enhance them further to promote new vessel formation and subsequently faster tissue recovery. In order to accomplish this task, growth factors or living cells can be attached to the ceramic before implantation. This project examined one possible method of attachment and the effects such a treatment would have on the biomaterial’s performance in vitro. That method of attachment was to use a cell-deposited layer of extracellular matrix (ECM) on the ceramics, the natural matrix that can perform all the desired functions described above.

The research was performed under the guidance of Dr. Yong-keun Lee’s Dental Biomaterials group at Yonsei University in Seoul, South Korea. Their previous studies in calcium phosphate biomaterials made the collaboration mutually beneficial. The project sought to quantify the amount of extracellular matrix deposited on three groups of fabricated calcium phosphate scaffolds; a control, one treatment group soaked in ostegenic medium, and the third treatment group precoated with ECM by cell culture. Prepared scaffold samples were brought to the host lab in order to measure the protein deposition, which could help in determining an optimal ECM coverage for the ceramics.

The experiment found an increasing amount of ECM over time on the ceramics from both treatment groups. Times points of 1, 7, 14, 21, and 28 days of culture were tested. After 14 days of culture, there was equivalent or significantly more mass of ECM found on either scaffold treatment group compared to the control. In addition, no adverse effects were seen in the behavior of cells grown on the treated scaffolds as determined by specific protein marker assays for cell development and cell number. The natural coating, achieved in the third treatment group with cell deposition, was determined to be a viable method of modification for the ceramics and a potential route for further development of bioengineered materials. Further studies could find methods of utilizing this natural ECM coating to locally deliver growth factors and cells in tandem with the calcium phosphate scaffold to improve neovascularization, tissue integration, or healing rate. The work leading up to this project has been submitted for publication, and further research with the ceramics is ongoing.


Last Modified: 07/27/2011
Modified by: Daniel A Young
